Award.AbstractNarration:
This project sits at the boundary between theoretical nuclear physics and particle astrophysics. Specifically, this research concerns the physics of neutrinos, elementary particles that are produced abundantly in stars and galaxies. These "astrophysical" neutrinos have been observed at Earth already and many more observations are expected in the near future. In this context, the theoretical research to be performed by the PI will play an important role in understanding the experimental data and will allow for new insights regarding the fundamental processes that take place in stars and the specific role played by the neutrino properties. In addition, this state-of-the-art research project will provide excellent opportunities for the training of students.

A major area of investigation in particle astrophysics concerns the physics of O(10) MeV neutrinos from core-collapse supernovae that presents a strategic opportunity for upcoming neutrino detectors. It is planned to study the potential of these detectors to measure the oscillation probabilities of neutrinos from a galactic supernova burst, with minimal theoretical priors, to distinguish different oscillation scenarios. Hours before a star becomes a supernova, neutrinos from the Silicon burning phase might be detectable. The flux of these neutrinos will be modeled in detail, using a new calculation method that includes the nuclear beta processes. Supernova neutrinos can also be detected in the form of diffuse flux from the cosmic population of supernovae. The study of this flux will be revitalized in the light of recent developments, with focus on detectability, and on the potential to measure important physical quantities from the diffuse flux. At higher energies, E ~ TeV - PeV, extraterrestrial neutrinos were discovered in 2013. This project considers star formation as a possible origin of these neutrinos. Positional coincidences of the neutrino data with known high-star formation regions will be studied quantitatively, and theory models of neutrino production in these regions will be developed.

This project is co-funded by the Division of Physics and the Division of Astronomical Sciences in the Directorate of Mathematical & Physical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, a team involving the principal investigator, a graduate student, and a postdoctoral fellow, in collaboration with other theorists, studied the theory of neutrinos that reach the Earth from stars, galaxies and the newly born universe. The main highlights are summarized here. 

 Neutrinos are elementary particles that are produced in very dense or hot astrophysical sites, where the fundamental processes at play are still poorly understood. Therefore, neutrinos are important messengers of these processes. The main outcomes of the project refer to three main areas. The first is neutrinos from very massive stars that will eventually explode as supernovae. Before the explosion, these stars become very powerful neutrino emitters. A new theoretical prediction of the flux of neutrinos expected in the last days of life of a star was produced, and used to show how, for a nearby star like Betelgeuse, these neutrinos can be detected. They can provide an alert to astronomers of the upcoming supernova, and reveal the approximate point in the sky where the supernova will occur. When the emission of neutrinos is as its maximum, the star will also emit gravitational waves. In this project, the possibility was examined to use the neutrinos and gravitational waves that will be detected in the future from a supernova to infer information about the way matter moves near the core of the star. As a first step, a detailed study focused on neutrinos was completed, another where neutrinos and gravitational waves are considered jointly is being prepared.  

A second area of investigation is the theoretical interpretation of the very energetic neutrinos from outside our galaxy that have been observed by the IceCube detector.  What produces these neutrinos is still unknown. In a series of papers, the team examined the possibility that some of the neutrinos might be the result of tidal disruption events, where supermassive black holes tear apart and swallow stars. Detailed predictions of the main features of neutrinos from tidal disruption events were worked out, and the specific case of a detected neutrino and its candidate tidal disruption event parent was examined. 

The third subject of study has to do with the role of neutrinos in the Early Universe, prior to the birth of stars and galaxies. A study was completed investigating the hypothesis that the Early Universe might have been populated by primordial black holes, which in the course of time would have emitted neutrinos. These neutrinos could still be present in the universe today and could, in principle, be observed.  

This project had an educational component, in the training of two young scientists, who have become proficient in the physics of neutrinos and its several ramifications into other fields like astronomy, cosmology, and experimental particle physics.
